thread.title: Track stars Angie Petty and Rosa Flanagan roped in for road relay race
thread.title_full: Track stars Angie Petty and Rosa Flanagan roped in for road relay race

title: Track stars Angie Petty and Rosa Flanagan roped in for road relay race
text:
Track stars Angie Petty and Rosa Flanagan roped in for road relay race Last updated 15:58, October 2 2015 Christian Petersen 
Angie Petty, pictured running at the world track and field championships in Beijing, will lead the University of Canterbury's bid for a national road relay title. 
World track and field championship athletes Angie Petty and Rosa Flanagan will spearhead the University of Canterbury's tilt at the national road relay championship title over the Takahe to Akaroa course near Christchurch. 
Petty, a 800m specialist, and steeplechaser Flanagan will be joined in the University team for Saturday's race by leading junior Gabrielle Gray, Alex Williams, Angela White, Nicki McFadzien, Rachel Kingsford and masters runner Maggie Chorley, who as Marg McKenzie still holds the masters women's lap six record. 
Their toughest opposition is likely to be from defending champions North Harbour Bays, comprising Esther Keown, Annika Pfitzinger, Charlotte Gordon, Leah Stanley, Lydia O'Donnell, Lana Van Hout, Anna Bramley and Lucy Van Dalen. 
Auckland City Athletic Club, surprise winners of the senior men's title last year will have their work cut out to contain a strong Wellington Scottish team and a rival Auckland team from Wesley. 
The ACA team came from 12th in 2013 in the Takahe to Akaroa eight lap 76.6km race to beat pre-race favourites and defending champions New Brighton Olympic over the same course last year. 
The relays have returned to Christchurch again to recognise and celebrate the 75th anniversary of the Takahe to Akaroa event. 
Scottish have a mixture of top middle distance runners through to mountain running exponents and long distance runners. Hamish Carson, national 3000m champion, will combine with national mountain running champion Dougal Thorburn, Australian based Ben Ashkettle, Australian based Japanese runner and winner of the Christchurch marathon Hiro Tanimoto, New Zealand mountain running representatives Stephen Day and Tim Hodge, Nick Horspool second in last year's Auckland marathon, and John Earles who was second in the Wellington road championships. 
Six members of the winning ACA team last year have returned, with Ben Moynihan, Jono Jackson, Simon Yarrow, Matt Baxter, Mike Banks and Josh Maisey all running this year. They are without two key players in their success last year, Mathew Mildenhall and Andrew Davidson. Harry Linford and Jake Wilkinson have been drafted. Wesley, after finishing fifth last year have worked on putting together a winning combination. National cross country and road champion Malcolm Hicks heads their line up and is well supported by Alex Parlane, Luke Hurring, Tony Payne, Will Harris, Peter Meffan, Liam Scopes and Sam Dobson. 
Pakuranga, fourth last year have called on national triathlon representatives Ryan Sissons, Cooper Rand and Jay Wallwork. New Brighton Olympic, the eight-time senior champions, have fielded Nick Rennie, Dave Ridley, Mark Bailey, Kerry Faass, Oska Inkster-Baynes, Dallas Wichman, Ryan Kiesanowski and Hayden McLaren. 
With 900 athletes representing 118 clubs, the road relay championships are Athletics New Zealand's largest championship event, numerically. 
Wellington Scottish, who are favoured to win the overall top club award have entered 11 teams and Wellington Harrier Athletic Club have 10 teams.
